items.title: Camerica Aladdin Deck Enhancer (nes_aladdin)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat

The Aladdin Deck Enhancer is a system-enhancing adaptor to use Compact Cartridges on the Nintendo Entertainment System. It was produced by Camerica and developed by Codemasters but not licensed by Nintendo.
 
The Aladdin Deck Enhancer contains a bypass Security Circuit Chip, a Memory Control Chip, and a Graphics Chip, which work with the lock-out chip and other features inside the NES. First, the Compact Cartridge is inserted into the Aladdin Deck Enhancer, which is shaped the same as a standard NES cartridge, and then this is inserted into the Control Deck. Inside the slot where the Compact Cartridge is placed is a recessed switch, which changes the Security/Region settings from position A to position B.
It contains 8 kilobytes of RAM for graphics use, and provides a cheaper means with which to make the game cartridges, mainly because each cartridge requires its own 10NES lock-out chip, RAM, and extra circuitry.

The package includes:

20 games (~122 MB)

items.title: SNK Hyper Neo Geo 64 (neogeo64)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat


Arcade system created by SNK, and released in September 1997, as the successor of the Neo Geo MVS, within the Neo Geo family.

It is the first and only SNK hardware set capable of rendering in 3D, and was meant to replace SNK's older MVS system on the market. Company executives planned for the project to bring SNK into the new era of 3D gaming that had arisen during the mid-1990s, and had planned for a corresponding home system to replace the aging and expensive AES home console.

However it never managed to match the huge success of the MVS, and reached its end of life in 1999. Only seven games were produced for the arcade variation of the system, none of which proved particularly popular, and the project was discontinued. The proposed home system never got beyond initial planning stages and only one of the arcade games, Fatal Fury: Wild Ambition, has been ported to home systems.

items.title: Namco System ES3 (namcoes3)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat


The Namco ES3 arcade platform runs on an nForce2-based motherboard that NVIDIA developed. It is based on a NVIDIA GeForce graphics card, using the OpenGL API. It uses a modified Japanese version of Windows Embedded Standard 7 as the operating system.

Namco ES3 games run in an arcade game cabinet designed by Bandai Namco Games.

The package includes:

14 games in pack for Batocera (~122 GB)
19 games in pack for Retrobat (~145 GB)

Pack for Batocera  Pack for Retrobat  

Batocera pack NOTE:
Requirements: RGS Batocera v40 with latest updates (check discord how to update)

Instructions: Drag and drop the "namcoes3" folder into the Roms directory.

Q: What is Arcade PC?
A: Arcade PC games are modern arcade games not playable with MAME, such as the BlazBlue series.

Q: Is this Teknoparrot?
A: Not quite. Teknoparrot is only a game launcher, and unfortunately, it does not work on Batocera/Linux.

Q: How does it work?
A: Launching Arcade PC games in Batocera is achieved using JConfig through Wine.

Q: What are JConfig and Wine?
A: JConfig is not just a program for launching recent arcade games; it includes a wide collection of launchers, tools, emulators, and patched executables for a better "arcade at home" experience. Wine enables Windows games/applications to run on Linux (Batocera).

Q: Does this sound complicated? Should we be worried?
A1: No need to worry! We've packaged the games to launch on most systems (Intel i5 / AMD Zen1).
A2: Namco ES3 games have been tested and working on AMD iGPU 3000 series and up, Intel i5/i7, RTX 2060. However Intel iGPU is no go.

Q: Is there anything else we need to know?
A: Yes, a few minor details:

- Most lightgun games require an actual lightgun (e.g., Sinden).
- Some lightgun games can be played with a mouse (a mouse indicator icon is present in the wheel).
- All games use a custom Wine GE runner and manual pad2key made by SPiRiT!
- A lot of Boxart is fictional as these games does not have boxart, missing boxart is custom created by G-spawn! ty ty!

How to install Batocera pack:
Drag and drop the "namcoes3" folder into the 'roms' directory and Enjoy!

 

Retrobat pack NOTE:
- Teknoparrot on RetroBat will auto configure controllers more info: https://wiki.retrobat.org/systems-and-emulators/supported-game-systems/arcade/teknoparrot
- If you want to setup your own controller, lightgun or steering wheel from Teknoparrot UI, you must disable autoconfigure controllers in RetroBat menu first RetroBat > Advanced Emualtor settings > autoconfigure controllers to OFF.
- To setup your APM3ID you have to go into RetroBat > Advanced Emualtor settings > User Interface and put in your profile name.
- All games have been tested and working to run on a i5 9th gen, Nvidia GTX 1050, RTX 3050
- The Teknoparrot launcher has been setup on R: but also tested on other drives, so far everything is portable

- When extracting or launching games your AV will trigger (Windows Defender), this almost always happens with teknoparrot games because there are patched .exe files. This is a false positive and you should exclude the RetroBat directory and Teknoparrot game files (including where you download it)
- Team Pixel Nostalgia can't support Teknoparrot, this has its own community with patches for GPU's etc.

Requirements: Windows 10,11 with VisualC runtime and Directplay, RetroBat 6.3.1 with RGS Latest update

VisualC AIO runtime: https://www.techpowerup.com/download/visual-c-redistributable-runtime-package-all-in-one/

DirectPlay: open a CMD as Admin,run:
CODE:

dism /online /Enable-Feature /FeatureName:DirectPlay /All

How to install Retrobat pack:
Drag and drop the "namcoes3" folder into the 'roms' directory and Enjoy!

items.title: Nichibutsu My Vision (myvision)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

The My Vision (Japanese: マイビジョン, Hepburn: Mai bijon) is a home video game console developed by Nichibutsu and released in Japan in 1983. The system was dedicated solely to playing video versions of popular board games.

My Vision came equipped with the same Texas Instruments graphics chip used in the ColecoVision and allowed both RF & composite video output. The console had no controllers; instead, players used a keyboard on the front of the console to input their actions.

items.title: M.U.G.E.N. (mugen)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat


M.U.G.E.N - a freeware program to create your own 2D games (brawlers), written in C. The game engine was released in 1999 by Elecbyte and was developed for the next four years. Since 2003 the company discontinued support for the engine, however Elecbyte returned to the engine development and released a new version in 2009. Updates released between 2004 and 2008 were unofficial versions of the original engine.

The word "mugen" probably comes from the Japanese language where it means dream, fantasy, or infinity. Officially Elecbyte claims to have forgotten what the acronym they chose for the name means, but the included documentation suggests that the engine was originally intended for use in shoot'em ups.

The engine is easily configurable. You can modify many elements of the game, including characters, arenas and the look of the engine itself. M.U.G.E.N community is centered around Internet themed forums, where users share the games they have created, as well as characters, which often represent characters from popular computer games.

The package includes:

85 game (~68 GB)

Go to download

items.title: Memotech MTX512 (mtx512)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

The Memotech MTX500 and MTX512 were a range of 8-bit Zilog Z80A based home computers released by the British company Memotech in 1983 and sold mainly in the UK, France, Germany and Scandinavia. Originally a manufacturer of memory add-ons for Sinclair machines, Memotech developed their own competing computer when it was perceived the expansion pack business would no longer be viable.

The Memotech machines were technically similar to, although not compatible with, the MSX standard, making use of the same CPU and video chip. The machines were particularly distinguished from other microcomputers available at the time by the generous maximum memory ceiling. The 500 and 512 models could be expanded internally up to 512K, an unusually large amount of RAM in 1983 for a computer aimed at home use.

items.title: Microsoft MSX Turbo R (msxturbor)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

The MSX Turbo R is the last generation of MSX computers that was put to market by a household electronic brand. Only Panasonic was brave enough to put faith in the standard once again, by releasing two different models: the Panasonic FS-A1ST and the Panasonic FS-A1GT. MSX Turbo R computers were produced until 1994.
New features include: a new PCM sound chip which can produce digitized sound up to 44 KHz (in assembly language) and a new Z80 downward compatible R800 processor. The user can select the CPU (Z80 or R800) by software.

According to Kay Nishi, the R on the MSX Turbo R stands for RISC (Reduced instruction set computing).

There is not a lot of software specific for the MSX Turbo R, although a lot of MSX games can run smoother and/or faster on an MSX Turbo R. As with the MSX2+, some software uses the optional scroll features or higher screens.

items.title: Palcom MSX Laserdisc (msxlaserdisk)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

LaserDisc is an optical disc technology, and looks like a very large CD-ROM. It was envisioned to be the future of Multimedia and was backed by amongst others Sony, Philips and Pioneer. While Philips never did anything with MSX and LaserDisc, Pioneer launched several MSX computers with integrated LaserDisc control ability, and various LaserDisc players.

While LaserDisc capable MSX systems from Pioneer were available in Japan, Europe and the US, commercially available software for the system was only published in Japan from 1984-1986 by the LaserDisc Corporation, a Pioneer subsidiary.

Later, Sony released exclusively in Europe a series of professional MSX2 computers with LaserDisc support, but no compatible software has been publicly released. One possible explanation is that this support was only used in-house by large media organisations which used these systems.

20 games (~16 GB)

Go to download

items.title: Microsoft MSX 2+ (msx2+)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

MSX 2 was an 8-bit computer standard introduced in 1985, a development of the MSX standard (later called MSX 1). Compared to its predecessor, it had enhanced graphics capabilities and the MSX DOS 2.0 operating system.

The MSX 2 standard did not gain much popularity, or even as much as MSX 1. After its introduction, Microsoft left the MSX project, but ASCII Corporation continued the work and in 1988 another improved MSX 2+ standard was presented, available only in Japan. In 1991 Panasonic unveiled a computer of the improved MSX Turbo R standard, but ceased their production as early as 1992. MSX computers were pushed out of the market with the dusk of 8-bit computers.

items.title: Microsoft MSX (msx)
items.content_html:
for Batocera and Retrobat

 

MSX is a standardized home computer architecture, announced by Microsoft and ASCII Corporation on June 16, 1983. It was initially conceived by Microsoft as a product for the Eastern sector, and jointly marketed by Kazuhiko Nishi, then vice-president at Microsoft and director at ASCII Corporation. Microsoft and Nishi conceived the project as an attempt to create unified standards among various home computing system manufacturers of the period, in the same fashion as the VHS standard for home video tape machines.

MSX systems were popular in Japan and several other countries. Sony was the primary manufacturer of MSX systems at the time of release, and throughout most of the products lifespan, producing more units than any other manufacturer. Eventually 5 million MSX-based units were sold in Japan alone. Despite Microsoft's involvement, few MSX-based machines were released in the United States.
